content.description:
Not my route and I didn't even have a chance to climb it. I don't know what or whose it is. Just pointing out that it exists.

There is a direct route and a variation that starts from the right so you don't have to climb through a bush.
content.protection: 6 bolts + 2 bolts with chains at the anchor
content.location: From the main area of the crag, walk due East toward the section of the cliff facing West Southwest. Look for the bolt line 200 feet left of the obvious dihedral.

content.description: Sweet ass movement on this beta-intensive 5.11. Knowing when to move right or left around the wide arete-like corner is key to success on this one. Onsightable for the strong, fun and workable for the intermediate. Safe falls the whole way, so get on it!
content.location: This is the middle right of the FOUR bolted lines on this wall.

content.description: Unknown sport route. Middle of the 3 sport routes.
content.location: Just left of center on the left-facing wall left of the 5.11 face.

content.description: Short, but fun sport route with interesting traversing moves on flakes and slopers. Very balancey moves throughout.
content.protection: 4 bolts + anchors. You might want a small piece or two for in between.
content.location: Left-most sport route around the corner from the others.

content.description:
This route provides some cool moves on bomber gear and is perhaps the most challenging trad route at the crag. The route climbs the hand crack (#3 Camalots) in a corner to some tricky moves in the roof to a fist crack (#4 Camalots) to the top. This route favors people with larger hands because the crack is on the larger side and might cause the climber to reach deep and trust baggy jams (let me know how the size treats you). If you wish to TR this route you can walk around the back of the cliff, following the cliff band around the corner and up through a corridor and a tricky scramble (I suggest using a rope but can be done without), this will put you on top, and a crawl under a shelf will lead you to the top of the climb where there is a old anchor constructed for rapellers consisting of 2 bolts and a old strap around a boulder (Bring some cord to assemble an anchor). With some effort and plenty of directionals the route can be top roped.

There is a shaky glue-in about 2 ft above the 2 bolt anchor, and is NOT to be used. This will be removed and filled.

There is a striking but faded petroglyph on the wall about 30 feet to climbers left from the base of the route, so be aware of it and help respect and protect this and other antiquities in the area!

Hey also this isn’t my route and has been climbing many times before me, please enjoy!
content.protection: Standard rack to a 2 bolt anchor with mussy hooks
content.location: The crack has an obvious overhang and is located just around the corner and right of “Far Right”

content.description: Far right near a large juniper. Starts on a face, uses a left-facing corner/finger crack, and finishes with a great (but short) hand crack to the anchors.
Double crack right in the middle of the wall. Fun!
content.location: Obvious double-crack with anchors right near where the access trail comes up

content.description: Sport face climb just left of the layback crack. Very crimpy, and not advised when the wall is getting blasted by the sun (speaking from personal experience).
content.location: Obvious face climb in the middle of the wall, left of the layback crack and right near where the access trail drops you.

content.description: Layback crack just to the left of the double crack. Make sure to bring #4 for the last move before the chains.
content.location: Just left of the double crack, right in the middle of the wall
